Comment: In almost all states, state legislative districts must be contiguous. In about half of the states, federal legislative districts must be contiguous.  However, contiguity is one of the criteria the federal courts use to determine whether a redistricting scheme is an illegal gerrymander. If your scheme is challenged and it has non-contiguous districts, it is highly likely to be struck down unless you manage to come up with a truly stellar justification for doing so.
